UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

It also allows for extending the behavior of a class without modifying the original code, promoting scalability.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a superclass with common properties and methods. âœ” Implementing a subclass that inherits and extends the functionality of the superclass. âœ” Overriding methods in the subclass to customize behavior (e.g., animalâ€™s generic behavior vs. dogâ€™s specific behavior). âœ” Understanding the inheritance flow and how a subclass inherits fields and methods from its superclass.Let me know if you'd like a detailed example or if you have any questions!Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

Here's a breakdown of the process:ğŸ“¥ I started by downloading a free CSS template, unzipping it, and organizing the files into a new folder. I renamed the default branch to main and pushed everything to a private GitHub repo using git push origin main.ğŸŒ Next, I created an AWS EC2 instance and connected to it via SSH. I installed Nginx on the instance with the following commands: sudo apt update sudo apt install nginx sudo systemctl start nginxâš™ï¸ In VS Code, I set up a .github folder with a cicd.yml file, defining a multi-stage CI/CD pipeline. Each deployment job (deploy-to-server-01 â†’ deploy-to-server-04) runs sequentially, automatically triggering after each commit to the main branch.ğŸ¥ Below is a video of my work where you can see the pipeline in action and how it all comes together.ğŸ’¬ Key Takeaways:âœ”ï¸  GitHub Actions simplified automating deployment, making it faster and error-free.âœ”ï¸  AWS EC2 provided reliable cloud infrastructure for hosting my project.âœ”ï¸  CI/CD pipelines are invaluable in streamlining development workflows and automating deployments, ensuring smooth updates to production.I'm excited to continue exploring these tools and techniques! UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

Here's a breakdown of the process:ğŸ“¥ I started by downloading a free CSS template, unzipping it, and organizing the files into a new folder. Then, I launched the project in VS Code using the terminal command code . to get started.ğŸ› ï¸ For version control, I initialized a Git repository with git init, staged and committed my changes with git add . and git commit -m "Initial commit". I renamed the default branch to main and pushed everything to a private GitHub repo using git push origin main.ğŸŒ Next, I created an AWS EC2 instance and connected to it via SSH. I installed Nginx on the instance with the following commands: sudo apt update sudo apt install nginx sudo systemctl start nginxâš™ï¸ In VS Code, I set up a .github folder with a cicd.yml file, defining a multi-stage CI/CD pipeline. Each deployment job (deploy-to-server-01 â†’ deploy-to-server-04) runs sequentially, automatically triggering after each commit to the main branch.ğŸ¥ Below is a video of my work where you can see the pipeline in action and how it all comes together.ğŸ’¬ Key Takeaways:âœ”ï¸  GitHub Actions simplified automating deployment, making it faster and error-free.âœ”ï¸  AWS EC2 provided reliable cloud infrastructure for hosting my project.âœ”ï¸  CI/CD pipelines are invaluable in streamlining development workflows and automating deployments, ensuring smooth updates to production.I'm excited to continue exploring these tools and techniques! UI-TARS-1.5 Outperforms OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s Computer Use Capability ByteDance has unveiled UI-TARS-1.5, an open-source multimodal agent that sets new benchmarks in GUI automation and virtual task execution.â€‹Built upon a robust vision-language model, UI-TARS-1.5 integrates advanced reinforcement learning to enable a "think-then-act" approach. This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

This design allows the agent to reason through tasks before execution, enhancing performance and adaptability in complex environments.â€‹Key achievements of UI-TARS-1.5 include:- Superior Benchmark Performance: Achieved 94.2% accuracy on ScreensSpot-V2 (GUI navigation benchmark) and 61.6% on ScreenSpotPro (complex UI task benchmark), outperforming previous state-of-the-art models like OpenAI Operator and Claudeâ€™s CLI-based agents in both low-level UI control and strategic planning.- Zero-shot Game Mastery: Achieved 100% success on 14 out-of-distribution GUI-based mini-games from Poki, demonstrating robust visual understanding and control policies.- Multi-step UI Task Solving: Efficient in long-horizon GUI tasks such as system settings configuration, tool navigation, and application control, without requiring fine-tuning on each app.UI-TARS-1.5 introduces a modular native agent architecture that fuses:- Perception (VLM)- Planning (Rationale Generator)- Memory- Action Execution (Click/Key APIs).This modularity allows the agent to generalize across unseen environment, paving the way for next-gen virtual assistants, automated QA, and enterprise RPA.â„¹ï¸ If you want to explore more please check my comments. hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AIAgents hashtag#Automation hashtag#RPA

In Intune, "update rings" refer to a strategy for rolling out Windows updates in stages, allowing administrators to test and refine the deployment process before a broad rollout. The common approach involves using a "Preview" ring (formerly "Pilot" ring), a "Limited" ring, and a "Broad" ring. This tiered approach helps minimize disruption and ensure a smooth update experience for the majority of users. Here's a breakdown of the typical update ring deployment strategy:1â€¢Preview (Pilot) Ring:A small group of test devices are assigned to this ring. This allows for initial testing and validation of the update before deploying it to a larger audience. 2â€¢Limited Ring:After the preview ring confirms that the update is stable, the "Limited" ring is deployed. This group is larger than the preview ring but still smaller than the overall organization. This provides additional feedback and opportunity to address any issues before broad deployment. 3â€¢Broad Ring: The final ring, the "Broad" ring, includes the majority of devices in the organization. The deployment to this ring is usually faster, as the risk of major issues has been minimized by the previous stages. Key Benefits of Update Rings:â€¢Reduced Risk:By deploying updates in stages, organizations can mitigate the risk of widespread issues and disruptions.â€¢Improved Testing:The tiered approach allows for thorough testing and validation of updates in a controlled environment.â€¢Targeted Deployment:Update rings can be configured to target specific devices or groups of users, enabling organizations to tailor the update experience to different needs and priorities.â€¢Enhanced Control:Administrators have granular control over when and how updates are deployed, including the ability to set deferrals and active hours.hashtag#Intune hashtag#Updaterings

Last week at nanoTRONIC, I successfully run a VHDL simulation that handles TM/TC and time synchronization over SpaceWire for an European Space Agency - ESA Earth observation mission.Our FPGA design handles: - SpaceWire I/F based on STAR-Dundee IP - SpaceWire redundancy - SpaceWire packet - CCSDS packet - Packet Utilization Standard (PUS)Figure on the top shows the SpaceWire initialization and transfer of time code (here we used it to received a Pulse Per Second (PPS) from the spacecraft):1. Simulation generates Din & Sin and sends specific characters to our design at 10Mbps.2. Our design is doing the same with Dout & Sout.3. Once both received the expected characters sequence, the SpaceWire connection is initialized and switches to its nominal speed.4. Simulation transfers a time-code.5. Our design decodes the time code and generates an internal PPS signal for our Local On Board Time (LOBT) design.The next figure shows transfer of a telecommand TC[9,128] that containsÂ the time needed by the LOBT for the next PPS:1. Simulation transfers a TC[9,128] to our design (including PUS header, CCSDS packet and SpaceWire packet encapsulation).2. Our design decodes the TC[9,128] and reception of this particular message is allowed.3. Our design generates a successful acceptance verification report telemetry TM[1,1] to acknowledge the TC[9,128] reception.4. The simulation detects a new reception and properly decodes TM[1,1].hashtag#VHDLdesign hashtag#SpaceWire hashtag#CCSDS hashtag#PUS hashtag#TMTC hashtag#EarthObservation

ğŸ’» Day 45: Method Overloading in SimpleMath ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of method overloading, where you define multiple methods with the same name but different parameter types or number of parameters within the same class. âœ… How method overloading allows the same operation to be performed on different data types (e.g., int vs. double), providing flexibility and readability in the code. âœ… Real-world example of method overloading (e.g., a SimpleMath class with overloaded add(), sub(), and div() methods to handle both integer and floating-point numbers).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Method overloading improves the versatility of your methods and makes your code more intuitive. Instead of creating multiple method names for similar operations, you can use the same method name with different parameters, keeping your code cleaner and easier to maintain. It helps you handle multiple scenarios with a single logical method name.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating overloaded methods with the same name but different parameter types (e.g., int vs. double). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls based on the number and type of arguments passed. âœ” Demonstrating method overloading with arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and division. âœ” Calling overloaded methods with different argument types and observing the results.Jain (Deemed-to-be University) Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.A Dr Sagar Gulati

ğŸ’» Day 44: Multilevel Inheritance in Java (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child) ğŸ§¬ğŸ”„ What You Explored: âœ… The concept of multilevel inheritance, where a class (Child) inherits from another class (Parent), and that class (Parent) inherits from a third class (Grandparent). âœ… How multilevel inheritance creates a chain of class relationships, allowing subclasses to inherit behavior from multiple levels of the class hierarchy. âœ… Real-world example of multilevel inheritance (e.g., a Grandparent class, a Parent class, and a Child class, where the child inherits behavior from both the parent and the grandparent).ğŸ”¥ Why It Matters: Multilevel inheritance enables you to build more complex hierarchies of classes, allowing for a more structured and reusable design. It encourages the reuse of code at each level of the hierarchy while also enabling specialization and extension of functionality in subclasses. This makes the code more organized, easier to maintain, and scalable.ğŸ† What You Practiced: âœ” Creating a class hierarchy where a subclass inherits from another subclass (Grandparent â†’ Parent â†’ Child). âœ” Understanding how each subclass can access properties and methods of its parent and grandparent classes. âœ” Demonstrating method inheritance and overriding in a multilevel context (e.g., showGrandparent(), showParent(), showChild()). âœ” Understanding how Java resolves method calls through the chain of inheritance.Jain (Deemed-to-be University)Dr. Sanjeev Kumar Mandal, Ph.D, M.C.A, B.C.ADr Sagar Gulati

The Rise of Freelancing in Pakistan â€“ A New Economic ForceFreelancing has rapidly become a game-changer for Pakistanâ€™s economy, offering a fresh path for income generation, especially among the youth. Here's how it's shaping up as a new economic force:Why Freelancing is Rising in PakistanWith over 60% of the population under 30, many Pakistanis are turning to online platforms like Upwork, Fiverr, and Freelancer to earn independently.Freelancing removes geographical barriers, allowing Pakistanis to work with international clients and earn in foreign currencies like USD, which boosts national foreign reserves.In a country where traditional job opportunities are limited, freelancing offers a flexible and low-barrier alternative to employment.Better internet infrastructure and government/private initiatives offering digital skills training (e.g., DigiSkills.pk) have enabled more people to work online.The pandemic normalized remote work worldwide, pushing both freelancers and clients toward online solutions.Why It MattersFreelancers earn in foreign currencies, contributing directly to Pakistanâ€™s foreign exchange reserves and reducing pressure on the trade balance.Freelancing lets skilled individuals earn globally without leaving the country, keeping talent at home.Freelancers often transition into entrepreneurs, building agencies or startups, which adds to economic dynamism.Freelancing offers income opportunities from home, especially empowering women and those in rural or underdeveloped regions.With proper regulation and tax policy, the government can tap into freelancing as a new tax base.Challenges AheadPayment Gateway Issues (like limited PayPal access)Lack of consistent government policySkills quality and client communication barriersCybersecurity and legal protections for freelancer.ConclusionFreelancing in Pakistan is more than just a trendâ€”itâ€™s a transformational economic force. With the right support, it can help reshape the economy by empowering individuals, bringing in foreign income, and creating a more inclusive job market.hashtag#freelancing
